title: UPSetting
historical_context: This article reflects the early 90s hacker culture, where physical package theft was seen as a form of rebellion and a way to exploit delivery systems.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, and individuals interested in unconventional methods of obtaining goods.
short_summary: The article describes a method called 'UPSetting,' which involves stealing packages from delivery trucks, particularly during the busy holiday season. It provides step-by-step instructions and tips for successfully executing this act without getting caught.
summary: The article goes on to provide additional tips for aspiring 'UPSetters,' such as the importance of removing any identifying labels from stolen packages to avoid detection. It also suggests knocking on doors before taking packages to ensure that no one is home, thereby reducing the risk of confrontation. The authors note that while UPS may provide more opportunities for theft, FedEx packages tend to be of higher value. Overall, 'UPSetting' serves as a guide for those looking to engage in this form of thievery, reflecting the rebellious spirit of the hacker culture of the time. The piece concludes with a disclaimer, distancing the authors from any legal repercussions of the actions described.
